title: I suppose ignoring the feminism scene is best.
body:
http://media.tumblr.com/63d7e2f88a0ccaf53d94d5079a8b77e1/tumblr_ncoae0a8gO1rh0f4io1_250.gif

You know people blindly agreeing with Taylor Swift on feminism and not even looking up the definition, which is...

-the advocacy of women's rights on the grounds of political, social, and economic equality to men.

This means that by definition if women have a right that is more biased towards them than men, you can't raise equality on men with the same right to that of women, because that's not what feminism is by definition.

However, the thing about the whole definition, is I see tons of people try to switch it around and say that feminism is about equality, yes, it's about equality for women, but necessarily for men, even so, there's already another word that fits equality better, which is egalitarianism.

-Egalitarianism (from French égal, meaning "equal")—or, rarely, equalitarianism or equalism—is a trend of thought that favors equality for all people. Egalitarian doctrines maintain that all humans are equal in fundamental worth or social status, according to the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy.

See? It clearly says it favors equality for all people, not just women, or men, or any specific thing on Earth.

Now I don't think feminism is a bad thing, it's definitely needed in third world countries, but the way people twist the definition, yell at people for not joining the movement, and actually do the opposite of what feminism is meant to do, just makes me want to ignore it completely.

So I guess ignoring it would be wise, you know, whenever I see it on the web I just scroll past it.

Anyways, have you guys ignored the chaotic scene of feminism on the web? Since, you know, radical feminists tend to stand out more, so trying to find actually ethical feminists can be tough at times and feel like they don't even get the attention they deserve for bringing the right kind of movement into play, which is sad, because it'd be wonderful if the web were filled with ethical feminists, not radical ones.
